Name: Hegemonia
Description:
Roughly translated from the publisher/ partners website:

In Hegemonia it is all about being the master of the Mediterranean. Military strength and tactical nous is necessary in order to take the Greek, Persian, Roman, Carthagenian or German to glory and prominence.

The battle for the Mediterranean impresses not only through simple rules, but also through extensive armies of over 100 highly detailed miniature models.

In German:

In Hegemonia dreht sich alles um die Vorherrschaft am Mittelmeer. Militärische Stärke und taktisches Geschick werden benötigt um die Griechen, Perser, Römer, Karthager oder Germanen zu Glanz und Gloria zu führen. Der Kampf um die Macht am Mittelmeer besticht nicht nur durch seine einfachen Spielregeln, sondern auch durch die umfangreiche Ausstattung mit über 100 detailliert modellierten Miniaturen.

Name: Armor Grid: Mech Attack!
Description: The first game in the Armor Grid System is Armor Grid: Mech Attack!  With an innovative game system and print and play 15mm scale Mech, Vehicle, and Infantry miniatures, this is a game of sci-fi mechanized military combat in skirmish and wargame scales.  Compete against your friends in one-on-one duels or extended military campaigns.

Name: Die kleinen Abenteurer
Description:
The board game shows a map of the eastern half of the world: Europe, Asia, Africa and Australia with part of Alaska.

The game is played by following the pattern of circles numbered 2 to 50. Circles 9,11,16,19,24,40 and 45 are red and represent rewards; circles 2,3,8,13,17,18,22,29,36,37,41,42,46 and 49 are white and represent forfeits. The rest of the circles are blue. You start at Berlin.

Published in Germany.

Name: Conquista la Corona
Description:
From box:
King Harold, had just returned to England from the Crusades, not time to declare his succession who dies suddenly.
Her 4 children are the heirs virtual, but only one can become the true king.
Each player will have to impersonate at beginning of the game the King is not entitled, to one of four colors, in defiance of all the others to become the authentic depositary of the Crown.
The achievement will not be easy! 
The game features 2 decks for a total of 90 cards.
Initially will distribute 8 cards of Army to each contestant and then they draw from the deck of event cards a card which constitute the performance of the real game.
Happen so bloody battles in which you can conquer Castles, Keys or Crowns, or see your Army decimated.
The game should be played in three round. Every round ends in two ways: one player obtains a "Full Victory" (Crown, Castle, Key of his colour and the Royal Seal) or all the Event cards have been turned up without a Full Victory.
In every case every player goes to mark on a paper his or her score.
It will also depend on luck but remember that amid the storms of events is not only the fate that you should count, but especially about your strategy skills, how to field Armies and your skill in negotiation.
There will then be unexpected as considerable pestilence, tax liability and Magicians are able to perform any spells.

Name: Flippin' Dolphins
Description:
Flip your hoops onto dolphins to win! Be the first player to score 50 points.

An electronic base unit containing 4 colored dolphin heads is turned on and rotates around while dolphin heads bob up and down.  Each player places one of his 10 rings on his seal's tail and flips the tailback to release the ring.  Players keep flipping rings until all 10 have been used.  This constitutes a round. AT the end of a round scores are tallied : 
A ring around a large spinning dolphin of your color: 5 points
A ring around and large color spinning dolphin: 3 points
A ring around any stationary gray dolphin: 1 point

Players keep playing round until a someone reaches a total score of 50 points.

Name: ASL: Journal – Issue Four
Description:
The ASL Journal is a magazine published by Multi-Man Publishing targeted specifically to ASL players. It contains strategy articles, explanations, after action reports, and, last but not least, a number of ASL scenarios.

1 sheet of 11 overlays.

From the publishers website:

				
				
					Articles
     History of the Game: Carriers - Coulda been a cupholder
     The Fine Art of Bushwhackin'  - Ambush and Close Combat - ASL Style
     Hall of Fame - The ASLML picks the scenarios
     Spotlight on Forgotten Vehicles - The Indian Pattern Carrier
     Abandoned at the Edge of the World - Indochina and ASL
     Scenario Analysis - Probing J24 Smashing The Third
     A View from the Mound - MMP on ASL
     Debriefing - Stomping on the Gremlins
     Tips for Learning ASL - That's a Mighty Big Binder...
     Bloody Omaha - SASL The Longest Day
     Hit 'em High or Hit 'em Low - Light Mortars and ASL
      'Bolts from Above - Highly Optional Weather Rules


				
				
					Scenarios
     Mission JM2 - Bloody Omaha    
     ASL Scenario J66 - Sound Retreat
     ASL Scenario J67 - The Lawless Roads
     ASL Scenario J68 - Unlucky Thirteenth
     ASL Scenario J69 - The Army at the Edge of the World
     ASL Scenario J70 - Just an Illusion
     ASL Scenario J71 - Tomforce
     ASL Scenario J72 - Cahier Carriers
     ASL Scenario J73 - Tired and Unsupported
     ASL Scenario J74 - Priests on the Line    
     ASL Scenario J75 - My Lonely Valentine
     ASL Scenario J76 - Ultimate Treachery
     ASL Scenario J77 - Moses' Blazes

Name: Mister Master
Description:
This is a football simulation performed with the cards.
It's possible to simulate any football game, a player against the other or in teams.
Players move with the launch of one or two dice on a default path, trying to end their movement on the boxes that allow him to play cards to attack.
If your opponent has cards appropriate defense, interrupts the action of attack and can leave again becoming he attacker, otherwise the first player to draw cards that will enable him to perform actions prior to center field, then in the area up to the shot.
A goal is scored when launching the special dice, you get the symbol on.
The game ends when the entire path will be traced. 
Obviously wins whoever  marked the most goals.
It is possible to conclude the match in a draw.

Name: ASL: Journal – Issue Three
Description:
The ASL Journal is a magazine published by Multi-Man Publishing targeted specifically to ASL players. It contains strategy articles, explanations, after action reports, and, last but not least, a number of ASL scenarios.

From the publishers website:
				
				
					Articles
      A View From the Mound - Curt Pontificates
      The Norwegian Campaign - April 9th - June 8th, 1940
      The French Expeditionary Corps - Victory at Narvik
      A Two Month Stint - The Chasseurs de Podhale
      HOCH! HOCH! - A Solitaire ASL Mission
      Slaughterhouse - A Scenario Review of J33
      A Case for Infiltration - Japanese Troops and Close Combat
      Collect for Output - How the Heck Did That Happen?!?
      Anti-Aircraft Guns - Employment and Tactics
      Strafer Jones Air Support Mechanics
      Broadway to Prokhorovka - A Kursk Mini-CG
      Keep on Truckin' - Truck Transport and ASL
      Rules of Engagement - Playing ASL with SASL Guildlines
      B9.5 BOCAGE - Historical and ASL Perspective
      Comprehensive Deluxe WA Example - Ian Mans the Wall
      American Tragedy - The Story Behind the Scenario
      First Do No Harm - Designer's Notes for the 2nd Edition ASLRB


				
				
					Scenarios
 
     Mission JM1     HOCH! HOCH!
     ASL Scenario J36 The Bridge of Verdalsora
     ASL Scenario J37 Tretten in Flames
     ASL Scenario J38 Bitter Defense at Otta
     ASL Scenario J39 Indeed!
     ASL Scenario J40 Might Makes Right
     ASL Scenario J41 By Ourselves
     ASL Scenario J42 Grebbe End
     ASL Scenario J43 3rd RTR In The Rain
     ASL Scenario J44 Audacity!
     ASL Scenario J45 The Last Roadblock
     ASL Scenario J46 Strongpoint 11
     ASL Scenario J47 They're Here! Reverse!
     ASL Scenario J48 Blood Enemies
     ASL Scenario J49 Desperate Dash
     ASL Scenario J50 The Cactus Farm
     ASL Scenario J51 Canicatti
     ASL Scenario J52 Dress Rehearsal
     ASL Scenario J53 Setting the Stage
     ASL Scenario J54 Showtime
     ASL Scenario J55 Matsumoto's Charge
     ASL Scenario J56 A Burnt Out Case
     ASL Scenario J57 Guards Artillery
     ASL Scenario J58 No 8 Platoon Overrun
     ASL Scenario J59 Friday The 13th
     ASL Scenario J60 Bad Luck
     ASL Scenario J61 In The Bag
     ASL Scenario J62 Lee's Charge
     ASL Scenario J63 Silesian Interlude
     ASL Scenario J64 American Tragedy
     ASL Scenario J65 Brave Little Emchas
     KGP Campaign Game IV Prayers In The Dark

Name: S'match
Description:
A Memory Matching Game with a Spin!
A new take on the classic memory game, S'Match challenges young players to find matching pairs by color, number or category. Only here, it's the S'Match Spinner that decides which way to match-and every player gets a spin! Pictures and words allow pre-readers and early readers to play together and enjoy hours of memory-building fun.

Name: ASL: Journal – Issue Six
Description:
The ASL Journal is a magazine published by Multi-Man Publishing targeted specifically to ASL players. It contains strategy articles, explanations, after action reports, and, last but not least, a number of ASL scenarios.

Besides the 12 scenarios, this issue also includes the Primsole Bridge Historical map, Chapter Z rules, (Z39-Z58), a campaign roster and purchase record, and three campaign games.

From the publishers website:

				
				
					Articles
     Series Replay: Tired and Unsupported (featuring Bocage)
     Residual Firepower and Firelanes
     Comprehensive Example on Residual Firepower and Firelanes
     The British in WWII (part 1 of 2)


				
				
					Scenarios
     J90 The Time of Humiliations - 8 turns, 1940 IndoChina
     J91 The Sooner The Better - 7 turns, large OB, 1941 Libya
     J92 Your Turn Now - 7 turns, 1942 Cebu Island
     J93 The Porechye Bridgehead - 9 turns, 1941 Russia
     J94 Kempf at Melikhovo - 4.5 turns, 1943 Russia
     J95 Typical German Response - 6 turns, 1943 Sicily
     J96 Another Bloody Attack - 6 turns, 1943 Sicily
     J97 A Nice Morning For A Ride - 6.5 turns, 1943 Sicily
     J98 Lend Lease Attack - 5.5 turns, 1944 Russia
     J99 On To Florence - 6.5 turns, 1944 Italy
     J100 For A Few Rounds More - 6.5 turns, 1945 Germany
     J101 The Coconut Plantation - 6.5 turns, 1945 Bougainville

Name: Partner
Description:
From Box:
Partner is a psychological game for 3,4,5 or 6 people.
Its purpose is to identify among the players, pairs of people, tastes, feelings, habits and tendencies have significant affinity.
With partners, therefore, not only form ideal couples in terms of sentiment, but their combination of persons who may have an effective agreement in other areas, such as business, entertainment, cultural interests and so on.
The game involves at any time all participants, who, responding to questions on the board should form a "chain of understanding" with another player.
Once it is formed a pair examined the psychological aspect.
Partner with discover in a fun and enjoyable nature of your relationships with others.
The results are surprising and unexpected!

Name: Wrap Cut Bang
Description:
The object of the game is to place all of your pieces onto the playing surface before your opponent can place all of theirs.

Each player receives 18 pieces in their colour.  The pieces either show a 'rock', 'scissors', or 'paper' symbol.  Each turn you must play your "reserve" tile that you selected the previous turn, and then select a new tile for your reserve, anticipating your opponent's next move.  Placements rules are basically that your symbol must overpower at least one other symbol beside it (using standard rock-scissors-paper rules.)  You lose a turn if you can't place your reserve piece onto the board, and you must then choose a new reserve piece for your next turn.

Name: Medieval Times Game
Description:
From the box: "New Family Game. Official Game of Medieval Times Dinner & Tournament. The Epic Game of Tournament Competition."

From the inner box: "My noble knights, you honor me with your presence. I Don Raimundo II, Count of Perelada, welcome you to my castle for a tournament of games. Now let the tournament begin!"

From the rules: "Be the first player to obtain all four tournament Victory Cards and present them to the Count and Countess at the Victory Banquet. The four tournaments are as follows: Sword Fighting, Ring Piercing, Jousting, Javelin throwing."

User summary: The game consists of a rolled-up cloth-backed faux-leather board with all four events located around the castle along with--in each corner--the sequence of moves to participate in each event; Fate cards, Victory cards in four colors: Salmon, Blue, Yellow and Green. 4 pewter knights in each of those colors; one die and the rules.

Name: Classical Hack Scenarios: Rome
Description:
Book Introduction:
"Classical Hack Scenarios is intended to provide historical miniature games interested in classical warfare with fast, playable, and entertaining scenarios.  The scenarios themselves are designed to be used with the Classical Hack game system.  Gamers can covert the lists to another system they wish with a little work on their part."

Historical Articles:

The First Roman Legion: Romulus 750 B.C.
Servian Changes (2 interpretations): 650 B.C. - 390 B.C.
Phalanx to Line: The Legion 390 B.C. - 200 B.C.
The Three Line Manipular Legion:  225 B.C. - 104 B.C.
Marian Changes:  100 B.C. - 6 A.D.
Augustus and After: 6 A.D. - 250 A.D.

Scenarios included:

Rome Fights Fidenae:  725 B.C.
Allia Valley:  390 B.C.
Heraclea: 280 B.C.
Asculum Second Day:  279 B.C.
Tunes: 255 B.C.
Battle of Ilipa:  206 B.C>
Cynoscephalae:  197 B.C.
A Campaign in Spain:  76 B.C. - 75 B.C.
Caesar and Pharnaces, Zela:  47 B.C.
Mons Graupius:  83 A.D.
Families: History: Wars of the Diadochi and Syrian Wars

Name: Classical Hack Scenarios: Macedonia
Description:
Scenarios designed for Classical Hack or other miniatures rules.

Scenarios:

Heraclea Lyncestis:  358 B.C.
Tamynae: 348 B.C.
Chaeronea: 338 B.C.
Mount Haemus: 335 B.C.
Lyginus:  335 B.C.
Alexander Against the Getae:  335 B.C.
Alexander at Pelium (3 scenarios):  335 B.C.
Alexander at Thebes: 335 B.C.
Granicus: 334 B.C.
Sagalassus: 334 B.C.
Issus: 333 B.C.
Gaugamela: 331 B.C.
Megalopolis: 331 B.C.
Persian Gates (2 scenarios): 330 B.C.
Eschate (2 scenarios): 328 B.C.
Arigaenum: 327 B.C.
Hydaspes (2 scenarios): 326 B.C.
Families: History: Greek & Persian conflicts of the 4th century BC
History: Wars of Alexander the Great

Name: Nexus Taxi
Description:
Designer Summary:

The galaxy is a busy place and no job is as busy as a taxi driver. Your job is to pilot your taxi ship through warp gates picking up and dropping off passengers. Be careful of the nexus though, should your ship stop there you never know where you will end up. Will you be the first taxi driver to deliver seven passengers before the work day is over?

Nexus Taxi is a light and chaotic two player print-and-play game.  Players will need, besides printing the game board, 1 ten-sided die, 14 passenger bits (such as cubes or meeples), and 2 taxis able to hold a passenger piece.

The game board and directions for play can be found in the image and files section (pending).

Name: Pole Position
Description:
User summary:
It is 'a tactical game that plays a Formula 1 race.
Established the grid through the roll of the dice, players take turns moving on the track, always throwing the dice.
Overtaking is allowed only in some parts of the circuit, so if we get a greater number of who goes before us but we can not overcome it, we can accumulate the points are not used to do so later (the primordial idea of KERS!).
Along the track there are also boxes of penalty that we are forced to miss turns, forced a pit stop etc....
The race includes the pit stop to change tires every 3 laps.
After the number of laps set earlier in the game (minimum 4) wins who crosses the finish line first.

Name: Sprizza la Parola
Description:
From box:
An original game, exciting, full on the Italian language.
3000 questions on 13 different topics: plurals,contrarys, foreign words, literature, mistakes ....
The simple and fast strategy involves and will challenge all players with fun challenges, risks, exciting and thrilling competition.

Name: L'inafferrabile U-BOOT
Description:
L'inafferrabile U-BOOT ("The Unseizable U-Boot") is a game that emphasizes skill and intelligence.

The ability to see enemy movements constitute the most valuable help to gain the victory.
The gambling behavior is not random, but determined by the navigation tools used according to the tactical thinking of the players.
The game represents the various stages of a battle between a German U-Boot and three Allied destroyers.
The U-Boot player wins entering the Base of destroyers, after covering all six areas that comprise the board, or sinking three destroyers.
Destroyers players win by sinking the U-Boot or if the U-Boot does not re-emerge within the set number of moves.

Name: Mini-Torreta
Description: The children use either the dice with colours or the dice with dots. Depending on the colour or number of dots that come up when the dice is thrown the children build towers and the winner is the one who stacks the bricks skilfully and produces the highest tower! Mini-Torreta will be delivered in a small cotton bag.

Name: Rasmus Klump: "Dyresnakspillet"
Description:
In this fun game for the whole family, players must help Rasmus Klump in gathering the things he'll need to bake a great pile of delicious pancakes with jam.
On their way, around the whole farm and the mill to gather the things, all the players will meet a lot of different animals, to whom they will have to speak to in "animal-language" - "Oink" for the pig, "meow" for cat, and so on.

Name: Pisa
Description: When a player rolls one of the colours on his square he may take a building peg and place it on the matching colour space. When a square is complete with building pegs the player may take a second square from the pile, place it on top of the completed square and continue building his tower. At the end the player with the tallest tower is the winner!

Name: Make A Match
Description:
From the back of the box:

Mixing and Matching fun for all ages.
Players roll the die and try to make as many mixed up comical characters as they can, choosing and combining card parts from different figures. The object then is to try to make complete figures by winning cards from other players. Each complete character scores one point, and the player with the most points wins!

Name: Plan West
Description:
Plan West™

- While Poland mobilizes and the diplomats try to find a peaceful solution to the Danzig situation, Hitler launches a back-stabbing attack without a formal declaration of war. Although England and France support Poland and on September the 3rd declare war on Germany, the Poles are left to fight alone….

Game components:
- Book-case box
- 70 x 50 cm map (28 x 20 in)
- 264 die-cut counters 
- Game rules 
- 1 die

In the late 1930s, Polish generals Berbecki, Bortnowski, Kasprzycki, Kutrzeba and Rómmel designed Plan West (Plan Zachód) for the defence against a German invasion. The planners had predicted the direction of most of the German thrusts, with the exception of the intensity of the flanking movement via Prussia and Slovakia. Although the Polish Army had already started their mobilization during mid-August, the final part was postponed until August the 30th due to the political situation and the work to find a diplomatic solution. However, on the German side, a general mobilization had already been completed under the cover of a military exercise, and the German army was deployed around the Polish border according to the German strategic invasion plan, Case White (Fall Weiß), originally developed by generals Blumentritt and von Manstein. 
 Plan West™ is an attempt to create a fun and fast-paced board game on one of the most decisive campaigns during World War II. The game is based around a chit-pull system and a Victory Point time track that forces the Germans to operate at a historical tempo during the game. Plan West™ covers the first 10 days of the campaign and is played on a coffee table sized map.

It is built around the same system of rules that shaped Stargard Solstice, Plan West and Army Group Narwa and utilizes a Command chit-pull system to activate HQ, which in turn allow their controlled combat units to move and attack.
Families: Series: Guerrilla Print (Three Crowns Game Productions)
Series: WWII Battle Series (Three Crowns Game Productions)

Name: Republic to Empire
Description:
From the Publisher's Website:

Wargaming the Wars of Napoleon Bonaparte.

Brought to you by the same team behind Beneath the Lily Banners, the book combines  the writing of Barry Hilton with the creative talents of illustrator and designer Clarence Harrison. The book is lavishly illustrated with over 200 original photographs shot especially.

150 pages of full colour with 210 photographs of some of the finest wargaming models around. The rules come with a six sided gate-fold full colour play sheet on thick gloss finish card.

The rules require no rebasing of collections. Unit basing is immaterial as long as it follows the general conventions of tabletop gaming. Republic to Empire can be used for all scales although they are primarily written for 28mm scale Divisional to Army level games.

Unit sizes can vary from 16-60 for infantry and 10 – 60 for cavalry. The game play is smooth and free flowing with minimal need to refer to the main text once concepts have been mastered. New players usually pick up the key mechanisms within three to four game turns.
 The rules contain comprehensive detail on

Scales – Creating your Army – Setting up the game – Command and Orders – Exploitation – Formations and Movement – Terrain effects – Skirmishers – Play Sequence – Artillery – Shooting – Charging – Close Combat – Resolve – Fighting in Built up Areas.

The text is laid out in a way that separates:

Background information on concepts

Core rule mechanisms

Examples of mechanisms at work

There a 10 page fully illustrated example game from the 100 Days Campaign with full detail from orbat construction to conclusion.

Special rules sections to cover adaption for the Revolutionary Wars Period and the 1812 War in North America are also included.

Name: Warhammer: Invasion – The Burning of Derricksburg
Description:
The seductive powers of Chaos have infiltrated the town of Derricksburg. Can one lone knight prevent them from spreading to nearby villages?

Fantasy Flight Games is pleased to announce the next Battle Pack for Warhammer: Invasion The Card Game, The Burning of Derricksburg! Check out “New Leaders and Ancient Enemies,” an introduction to this exciting new cycle... then this summer, prepare to settle the score with your greatest foe.

The Burning of Derricksburg is the first Battle Pack installment of The Enemy Cycle, a linked expansion series for Warhammer: Invasion, a card game of intense warfare, clever kingdom management, and epic questing.

This 60 card pack contains 20 different never-before-seen cards designed to augment existing decks and add variety to the Warhammer: Invasion metagame.

What’s more, The Burning of Derricksburg is the first Battle Pack for Warhammer: Invasion to adopt the versatile new collation format, meaning you’ll receive three copies each of all twenty cards in one convenient purchase! From Fantasy Flight Flight Games
Families: Collectible: Living Card Game (Fantasy Flight Games)
Game: Warhammer Invasion – Living Card Game

Name: KnowMe
Description:
From the publisher:

Get to know your co-workers and friends better in 3 hours than you normally would in 3 years!

This unique board game gives players the chance to choose the type of questions they answer, but the easier the question, the fewer the points. Questions can have you trading shoes with the person across from you, asking the group what they think of your smile, or describing your relationship with your mother. You never know what the next question will be . . .

Use it to:

*      Integrate Teams
    *      Manage Change
    *      Turn Diversity into Strength
    *      Improve Communication

Create an atmosphere of trust among players and have fun getting to KnowMe™!

Name: Under the North Star: The Finnish Civil War 1918
Description: A two player simulation of the Finnish Civil War that cost the lives of over 37,000 Finns. The war was fought in Finland from 27 January to 15 May 1918 between the forces of the Social Democrats led by the People's Deputation of Finland, commonly called the "Reds", and the forces of the non-socialist, conservative-led Senate, commonly called the "Whites". The Reds were supported by Russian Soviet Federative Socialist Republic, while the Whites received military assistance from Sweden and the German Empire.

Name: Babes in the Wood
Description:
The game consists of a 3D plan of a little cottage. There are two platforms on each side of the roof where Hansel climbs to throw down ginger.

Below stands Gretel who catches the pieces of ginger. There are six places where Gretel can stand on each side of the cottage and each side of the roof.

You can move Hansel and Gretel according to the throw of the dice. Hansel can move one platform up or down, and Gretel can move to an adjacent place on the ground. A third option given on the dice is for Hansel to throw down one ginger by sliding new tile from the bundle on the table.

Each platform of the roof consists of six ginger tiles. On the other side of the tile are one or three almonds, but there can also be a witch who can catch Gretel and force her to give up one ginger tile.

The game ends when there are no tiles to put on the roof. Whoever has collected the most almonds wins.

Name: Emil und die Detektive
Description:
The board shows a city with lots of high buildings between which the players roll and move. When a player pawn reaches a black field, the player can look at the top face-down tile next to it and keep it if so desired. If not, he/she puts it back on top of any stack. When a player rolls a 6, he/she can demand a tile from another player who has four tiles or more. The goal is to collect a thief tile and exactly 140 Marks (money tiles come in 50s, 20s and 10s). The first player to achieve this is the winner.

(user summary)

Name: Blue Chip
Description:
Blue Chip is played on a 8x8 square board. On each turn each player must do the next two things:

1. Pass or move one of his stones as a "runaway queen" (i.e., to the last empty cell in any direction, but not to any closer square), if and only if the stone is orthogonally adjacent to a neutral blue stone at the start of its move.

2. Pass or move a neutral blue stone as a "runaway queen", if and only if it is orthogonally adjacent to any non-neutral stone (red or white) at the start of its move. If this move leaves the stone orthogonally adjacent to a red or white stone, the same stone may move again, and so on.

GOAL - A player wins when his first row is filled with stones, including at least one of his color. If neither player's first row is filled yet neither player is able to move, the last player who moved loses.

Name: Memoir '44: Breakthrough
Description:
From the Days of Wonder website:

Go deep behind enemy lines at Sword Beach as you airdrop in to capture the bridges of the Orne… Join Guderian’s famed Panzers as they battle the armored columns of the British Expeditionary Forces… Sign on for Operation Crusader to take on Rommel in the deserts of North Africa and liberate the garrison in Tobruk…

The Memoir ‘44 Breakthrough Expansion will take you deep into the battles of World War II with two, double-sided, 9-panel board maps covering all four Memoir ‘44 map environments - countryside, beach, winter and deserts. These oversize boards stretch the limit of current printing technology and are 13 x 17 hexes deep, opening up the Breakthrough format to new, more expansive scenarios.

The Breakthrough Expansion includes 15, never-in-print-before scenarios, created by Jacques “jdRommel” David, and Memoir ‘44 author, Richard Borg. These scenarios cover the Western and Eastern Fronts, as well as the Mediterranean and Pacific Theaters and include classic battles such as: Operation Crusader; Operation Amherst; and two different renditions of Sword Beach - all designed for the 13 x 17 hex Breakthrough format.

Name: Kreuzwort-Pulok
Description:
Kreuzwort-Pulok is a collection of games with the same materials: 256 letter tiles (15 don't have letters, but faces on them - these are wildcards) and a grid board for each player that is protected from the view of other players by an integrated paper screen. There also is a cardboard "plate" (a round disk for discarded tiles).

The goal is to form crosswords on the grid boards. There are ten games included:

Sechzehner-Spiel: Each player has to form a word that someone announced. Tiles not needed for this are used for crossing words. Tiles are drawn and discarded (openly, so other players can grab the discarded ones). When the first player finishes, the other get penalties depending on the number of tiles left over and the number of tiles missing for the basic word.

Fünfer-Spiel: Each player has to form a cross of two words with five tiles. When that isn't possible, additional tiles are drawn, but not more than two unused ones can be held in the end. The first player to achieve a legal crossword scores points.

Achter-Spiel: Same as the Fünfer-Spiel, but two or more crosses have to be formed, three tiles can be kept.

Kaufspiel (for two players): Each player draws ten tiles and looks at them without sorting them. The active player can then announce "buying" or "playing". When buying, he/she also announces a number of tiles. Both players now have to discard this number of tiles and redraw them. When playing, both try to form a legal cross with their tiles. The winning player gets 10-15 points, the other one a penalty depending on the number of unused tiles.

Leiter: Two columns of ten letters each are places on the table. The task of the players is to extend each pair of letters in one row into words. Thus they can get rid of their tiles. A player who cannot play has to draw a new tile. The first player to get rid of his/her tiles is the winner.

Gruppenspiel: Similar to Leiter, but with an open cross instead of fixed columns. So the players can add tiles in any direction, as long as the letter combination occurs in a German word.

Wettrennen: Each player gets 19 tiles and secretly forms a cross using at least 11 tiles. The score of the first player to achieve this is 10 plus the last digit squared (11 to 91 points). The other players lose one point for each unused tile.

Wörter anbinden: A letter is placed on the table. Each player takes turns to add a letter, but the letters still have to form the beginning of a word. When that is not possible, all but the last (at least) two tiles are discarded and the last letters start the new word. The first player who can use up his/her tiles is the winner.

Ausfüllspiel: Three letters are flipped open on the plate in the middle of the table. All players now try to form a word which uses two of these letters as first and last letters. The first player to manage this is the winner.

Alleinspiel: A collection of four solitaire games.

The designer of Kreuzwort-Pulok is uncredited, but the preface is signed "J.M." (It seems likely, but isn't entirely clear whether these are the initials of the designer).

(User Summary by HilkMAN)

Name: The Grass of Parnassus
Description:
A strategy/fantasy game played on two decks of standard poker-style playing cards, the basic idea behind The Grass of Parnassus was to create a fun strategy game which could be played on standard cards.

Each player has a city. The objective is to either build your city to a strength of 15 or to pummel your enemy's city to a strength of zero. Each player holds two "decks" of cards - a resource and action deck. Action cards may be played if the player has the corresponding resource cards to spend. Actions include strenghtening your city, hiring a champion to defend your city, deploying spies and thieves, and attacking the enemy city or champion.

Though intended for two players, up to four may play at one time by adding one deck for each additional player; this may add more dimensions to the game as alliances and cooperatives may be formed and broken.

The play is not too intense, though planning a few turns ahead is essential to success.

Name: Captain Soul Adventure Game
Description: A somewhat Blaxploitation roll and move game (spinner) where you play "Captain Soul" a Black super hero battling the forces of evil while exploring outer space.

Name: El Condor Pasa
Description:
You and your Condors' family have to take as much carrion you can, in the hope of earning more victory points than the others condors' family.

Flying from a big tree, the condors will land to take carrions - earning some victory points.
But, standing on the tree, the condors will make the most victory points that will give the final victory to your condors' family.

Now it's your turn to take a chance to make more victory points than other condos' family. Take your water and beware from bones, rattle snakes, cactus and be fast so you'll win your prize: the better place on the condors' tree!

Name: Max-It
Description:
From rules page:

Max-It is a unique dice game played with a special set of five dice. Three regular d6s and two "function" dice, each of which has two Plus (positive) signs, two Minus (negative) signs and two Times (multiplication) signs. Game play involves rolling and re-rolling the dice, and grouping them in various combinations to produce the most desired results.

The game is divided into three rounds, each with a different objective. A round consists of three turns and a Max-It roll for each player. A Max-It roll uses only two dice, one regular and one function, and may cause a scoring upset. After three rounds, each player takes a final Max-It roll. The player with the highest total score wins.

Round 1 - Players try for high positive scores.
Round 2 - Players try for high negative scores.
Round 3 - Players try for the greatest difference between two dice rolls.

Components include 5 dice (3 regular and 2 function), dice cup, instructions and players' score pad.

Name: Push
Description:
Push is played on a initial empty 8x8 board.
Each player inserts a stone onto the board from an edge.
The push may be horizontal,vertical or diagonal,but must be away from the pushing edge.
Passing is not allowed.
If a stone,when pushed meets another stone,this too is pushed on the same direction,and so on.
Wins the player which has 5 stones in a row.

Name: Admiral Byrd's South Pole Game 'Little America'
Description:
Follow Rear Admiral Richard Evelyn Byrd, Jr., USN (1888–1957) on his trail by air, sea and land from New Zealand to the South Pole avoiding the perils of icebergs, crevasses and blizzards along your route.

Housed in the original 2 part box with color illustration on box lid depiction Admiral Byrd and scenes from his Antarctic exploration: Game board, 4 wooden game pieces, 4 spinners mounted to wooden sticks with colored cords and wooden plugs simulating radio microphones.

Object of the game is to insert peg at bottom of microphone into die-cut holes at “New Zealand”, spin the spinner and start out for Admiral Byrd’s Little America base. As players reach their destination they announce their safe arrival using the microphone and then continue on to the South Pole. The first player to reach the South Pole by exact count wins.

Name: Zombie Office
Description:
'Zombie Office' begins with players attending another boring birthday party at the office. The boss is leading them in a verse of 'happy birthday' when an accumulation of chemicals finally take their hold on his squishy brain, turning him into an enraged, flesh-craving zombie. Run for your LIVES!!!

Run into nearby rooms, search for office supplies to use as weapons and other useful items, screw over your coworkers or work together to survive; but remember, there's only one first-place!

One player starts as the original zombie and chases down the human players, attacking and changing them into fellow zombies whom join in the frenzy, hopefully infecting everyone before the police arrive.

"This job really bites!"

Name: Krazy Bee Rummy
Description:
A set collecting, rummy card game played in multiple hands.

Players must collect 14 different card sets or "steps", one per hand,  in a specific order, with an increasing level of difficulty.  On a players turn they must draw a card, complete a step if possible or play off cards from their hand onto their own or other players steps if they have their target step "down", and discard a card to end their turn.  If player discards a playable card, another player may call "rummy", play the card from the discard, and give the discarding player a card from their own hand.  A hand of play ends when any player discards the last card from their hand.

Players score points for cards remaining in their hands at the end of each hand of play.  After completing all 14 steps, the player with the lowest score wins.

Game includes 143 card deck (featuring unsuited number cards from 1 to 13 and "Wild Bee" wild cards), a set of four unique sliding windowed step counters that allow each player to keep track of which of the 14 steps he or she is trying to "get down" next, and a large pad of score sheets.  Cards are linen finished and seem to be of high quality.  Box top is sturdy.  Inner box, with game rules printed on bottom, is somewhat flimsy.

Name: Jeu du Grand-Homme
Description:
This game, the name of which translates to 'Game of a Great Man', celebrates the important events in the life of Napoleon I (1769-1821). There are 63 playing spaces, with representations or allegories of events in the Life of Napoleon I.The rules are engraved in the centre of the game board.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns, taking of counters. 
Forfeits: backward movment, lose of turns, payment of counters. 
Equipment required: teetotum and playing counters.

Published in Paris, France.

Name: Jeu des Monuments de Paris
Description:
The name of this game translates to 'Game of Parisian Monuments'. There are 63 playing spaces which represent places of interest in Paris with additional scenes in the corners. The end of the game is marked with the Arc de Triomphe. Rules are engraved in the centre of the game board.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns, taking of counters. 
Forfeits: backward movment, lose of turns, payment of counters. 
Equipment required: teetotum and playing counters.

Published in Paris, France.

Name: Dondi Finders Keepers Game
Description: Simple roll and move track game featuring the comic strip character who was drawn from 1955 until 1986.

Name: Jostle
Description: Jostle is a combinatorial game (i.e. two player, perfect info, etc.), which uses a 10x10 square grid, 16 red checkers and 16 blue checkers, as shown in the figure.  On your turn you move one of your checkers to an unoccupied, orthogonally adjacent square, subject to the following.  The value of a checker is its number of friendly orthogonal adjacencies minus its number of enemy orthogonal adjacencies.  You can only move a checker when you increase the moved checker's value.  The last player to move wins.  I.e. if you don't have a move on your turn, you lose.

Name: Warhammer 40,000: Spearhead
Description:
Spearhead is a new way to play Warhammer 40,000 that enables you to unleash exciting tank battles and daring breakthrough missions on the tabletop, bringing the full mechanised fury of the 41st Millennium to bear in your games. June's White Dwarf will contain the main part of the supplement, including new rules and missions.
(from publisher)
Spearhead will make use of forces totally consisting of vechiles or monstrous creatures (in the case of the Tyranid and Daemon armies). This radical change from established Warhammer 40,00 will involve necessary changes to many core aspects of the rules system, most notably deployment of forces.

Name: Monopoly: New Orleans Saints Super Bowl XLIV Champions Collector's Edition
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

The Saints are marching back to New Orleans with their first Super Bowl Championship!

The MONOPOLY brand proudly presents the New Orleans Saints Super Bowl XLIV Champions Collector’s Edition. Buy, sell and trade Drew Brees, Reggie Bush, Darren Sharper, Marques Colston and Robert Meachem in an effort to own the NFL’s best. Relive the road to glory from their 13-game winning streak to Garrett Hartley’s game winning overtime field goal against the Vikings.

Congratulations to all Saints fans and to the city of New Orleans on your first Super Bowl victory in franchise history!

Name: Monopoly: Fabulous Las Vegas Edition
Description:
Publisher Blurb:

Jackpot!

Buy, sell and trade the most popular hotels and casinos in Las Vegas right now! Wheel and deal Caesars Palace, Bellagio, Planet Hollywood, Stratosphere and the Red Rock in an effort to own and control the Entertainment Capitol of the World, Las Vegas. Become the "Kingpin" of America’s favorite board game, MONOPOLY, the Las Vegas Edition.

Includes 6 custom pewter tokens: roulette wheel, wedding chapel, stack of money, poker chips and showgirl.

Name: Treachery: A Fantasy Warlord scenario
Description:
User Summery:
When a local Duke decides to kidnap and ransom the leader of a mercenary group he's had under his employ in order to recoup some of his payroll, the Duke finds himself in a small war with a band of hardened fighters.

The Duke's forces include well-trained Humans and a small number of Dwarves while the Mercenaries contain a motley mix of Humans and Wood-elves. The Mercenaries main objective is to free their leader, L'Naiden, while the Duke is trying to hang on to the leader while crushing the Mercenaries.

This scenario appears in Red Giant (Volume 1, Number 2 - 1990) magazine.

Name: Dawn of the Dice of the Dead
Description:
Dawn of the Dice of the Dead is a cooperative horror survival game for 1-4 players based on the dice system created by Mads Brynnum for Dice of the Living Dead.  The game adds an epic storyline and a multiplayer framework, as well as new mechanics.  Players represent survivor groups who have a limited time to search through an abandoned mall to find supplies and materials that will help them be rescued, all the while fighting off ravenous zombies.

Dawn of the Dice of the Dead can be played solo by controlling 1-4 survivor groups, or cooperatively by 2-4 players.

As of March 2010, a print-and-play playtest version is expected to be available soon, as well as a Vassal module.

Name: Hockey Tivitz
Description:
Educational Math board game that uses checkers type movement. The playing pieces called "Tivit"s are 6 sided dice with each side having a symbol and numerical value. The 2 players race to reach the opposite side of the board, forcing them to cross paths and allowing for opportunities to jump over other pieces. Each location at the other side of the arena (board) has a mathematical operation(addition, subtraction, multiplication or division). A players score is the value of their Tivit adjusted for the math operation for each Tivit associated with their final location.

The game includes 30 different paper boards with varying degrees of difficulty. For ages 8 and up.

Name: Le Nouveau Jeu du Costume et des Coeffures des Dames
Description:
In each corner of the sheet is a scene for a different part of the day showing a woman engaged in a relevant pursuit such as dressing and hunting.

The game board has 63 numbered compartments, each showing the head of a lady. The rules are in the centre. This game is dedicated to the beautiful sex.

Name: Round the Town
Description:
A race around London on tracks, illustrated with various well known buildings.

There are eight starting points, all on the outskirts of London and each with numbered routes. The aim is to be the first player to reach the centre of London, marked by Charing Cross. There are 8 playing pieces.

Designed in England and printed in Germany.

Name: The Day's Doings of a Little Mouse: An Amusing Game for Learning French
Description:
This game has 100 playing spaces. Players follow a young mouse from the time he gets up in the morning until he goes to bed at night. The French instructions are printed on the game board.

All numbers and rules are in French and the game was designed to teach the language.

Rewards: forward movement, extra turns. 
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turned.

Name: The Wild Wood
Description:
The board is laid out with a tree in each corner and a clearing in the centre. Players move along pathways that connect the different areas, and they follow printed directions, which include both forfeits and rewards. In the middle of each outer edge is a store comprising four oval spaces on which players place the food they have gathered. The playing pieces represent four woodland animals: a wood mouse, a red squirrel, a bank vole and a harvest mouse.

The game requires the players to gather winter stores for the animals and attempts to instill knowledge about the animals.

Rewards: forward movement, collect items. 
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turns and forfeit of items 
Equipment required: 4 round markers of stained wood, green with a paper label showing a woodland animal, 16 tokens, ovals of printed card - four each of acorns, beechnuts, pine cones,  hazel nuts and wooden dice.

Published in the UK.

Name: Winnie the Pooh's Race Game
Description:
Do you love A. A. Milne's Winnie The Pooh? OK, here is the race game! On the game board one can see some of the adventures  to be found in the books of Milne.

Published in London, UK.

Name: Little Noddy's Train Game
Description:
This game uses the children's book character, Noddy, created by Enid Blyton in 1949. It is a four-track race game in which each player has a plastic playing piece in the shape of a railway engine. The pieces are of different colours, matching the colours of the four tracks. Players use a spinner instead of dice and they follow instructions that are given along the trackways.

Rewards: forward movement. 
Forfeits: backward movement, missed turns. 
Equipment required: markers, in the form of a steam engine driven by Noddy, coloured plastic, teetotum, marked 1 to 6.

Name: Steel Bonnets: Skirmish Rules for 16th Century Border Reivers
Description:
From the introduction of the rules set:
"Fraser's book The Steel Bonnets gives a good history of the cattle raids back and forth across the Anglo-Scottish border during Elizabeth's reign. Having visited Hexham, capital of the Middle March last year, and toured the first purpose-built gaol in England, my interest in the Border Reivers was rekindled and I devised the following game.

"Being both a wargamer and a role player I was interested in developing a fast, easy set of rules suitable for a skirmish encounter while instilling a sense of proprietary interest on the part of the players with their figures. Too often, I find, tabletop generals are willing to sacrifice their regiments with gleeful abandon, heedless of the actual cost. Role playing games generate a notion of investment and caution, with characters developed over a series of adventures. Steel Bonnets attempts to recreate the care and concern a reiver patriarch would feel for his sons and gillies when they are on raid."

Scale: One turn equals one minute; one figure equals one man; half an inch equals one yard. 20mm or 25mm figures are recommended.

Although a miniatures game, figures have individual characteristics and skills that develop over time.

This simple system includes rules for Spotting and Victory Point, as well as everything need for combat. Includes four scenarios: The Cattle Raid, Black Mail, Government Raid, & Gaol Break.

Rules set appear in Wargames Illustrated #78 (March 1994)

Name: Slobbering Mutants
Description:
This is a game where players move their pawns around a hexagonal-grid board, and absorb bursts of radioactivity.  These bursts occur at random locations.  Each player uses the radiation they absorb to acquire cards with different abilities. The players battle each other until there is only one player left.
The Mutant Abilities are tongue-in-cheek, and are of three different types, depending on the type of radiation absorbed: Alpha, Beta, or Gamma.
The players track their hit points on seperate player sheets with plastic tokens.

There are expanded rules for serial/campaign play where players keep some attributes between games.

Name: La Vie Humaine un Nouveau Jeu
Description:
The boardgame has 84 playing spaces. The main title and the individual ones are in four languages: French, German, English and Polish. The aim is to reach immortality, and the end space of the game is the Immortal Man. It shows a memorial monument with an urn on the shoulders of women who stand on a column and steps, accompanied by four figures. On the memorial tablet are the words ‘MLEOPOLD/HERvBRAUNS/GEB1752GEST85’, which refer to Leopold of Brunswick, who drowned in 1785 while attempting to save people in a flood. He would have featured here as a model of selflessness, which was considered one of the qualities needed to attain eternal life.

Rewards: receipt stakes and/or moves forward, according to the rules. 
Forfeits: payment of stakes (counters) and/or moving backwards or staying an extra turn in one spot, in accordance to the rules. 
Equipment required: teetotum, one marker per player; at least 12 counters per player.

Name: Cutlass of Cheese
Description:
This is a dungeon crawl created by the same designer as "Cutlass of Fire" and made to poke fun at it. The rules are filled with funny references to the game itself and the previous game.  
Squares are laid face down on the table and turned up as player put their pawns on them.  The player will encounter walls, monsters, skulls, fountains, and treasure chests.  By using cards for all actions except moving, the players battle monsters, find gems, and find spells, weapons and armor.  The players' ability to use the items depends on their skills. Spell skills are based on the known elements of the universe, namely: Cheese, Nougat, Lint, and Uranium 236. Weapon skills could be: Stabby, Pummely, Huckey, and Minty Fresh.  The number of hits a player or monster can take is called, "Chutzpah."  The game ends when 7 gems are returned to 7 skulls (just like Cutlass of Fire) and the player with the most points wins.

Name: Le Grand Terme ou Le Jeu des Temps
Description: The boardgame was designed for the German and French market and uses those two languages. The starting point is a clock face numbered 1 and entitled 'Temporellite' or 'Zeirlichkeit' and the finishing point is number 33, 'Eternity'. Some of the squares require the receiving or paying of a token and some send the player forwards or backwards. The game would be played with dice. The player going out on the number 33 will win.

Name: Medusa
Description:
Medusa is a Go game played on a base-10 hexboard with 61 'holes', so that a corner cell has 2 liberties, a cell on the edge 3, and a cell on the inside 4, as in regular Go.

On each turn a player has the following options:

     Drop a stone on an empty cell.
     Move one or more of his groups (a group is a set of connected stones).
     Drop a stone and then move one or more groups.
     Pass.


The player with more points wins.  Points awarded:

     One point for each stone.
     One point for each surrounded cell.

Name: Bob's: The Great War Game
Description:
The game deals with the Boer Wars, two wars fought between Britain and the two independent Boer republics, the Orange Free State and the South African Republic (Transvaal Republic).  The First Anglo-Boer War (1880–1881) and The Second War (1899-1902).

This is a strategy game in which the two players attempt to reach their goals, while halting the progress of their opponent.

Name: Game of Strategy
Description:
The game board shows a cavalry headquarters in the centre and the implements of war in each corner.

Counters: 16 black and 16 white.
Spinner: With two arrows.

Name: Transports
Description:
The gameboard shows 3 islands, 6 ships and two opposing fortified harbours with their areas marked off with blacklines.

This game was published shortly before the outbreak of the First World War in 1914. It requires the Red Fleet to move its transports from one safe harbour to another while under the protection of battleships, destroyers and cruisers. Its enemy, the Black Fleet, attempts to capture the red side's transports. Rules govern the movement of each vessel, and there are a number of islands that have to be avoided. The Black Fleet is not allowed to enter the harbours. The game is won or lost if the transports are successful.

Equipment: 13 triangular cards each with a picture of a ship and a letter, these represents two fleets (red and black) and various ships: transports, battleships, destroyers and cruisers.

Published in London.

Name: Sink the Submarine
Description:
This game is a straightforward race game with an unusual pattern of play with 104 squares set up and down the board around the central illustration with naval warfare, which is the finish.

Published in England.

Name: The new game of Jutland: A fascinating game of naval strategy
Description:
The game requires each player to position his fleet on the pad and guess the position of their opponent. The winner is the one who finds out the opponent's position first.

Each player takes a pad of charts and decides whether he shall be Blue or Red. He then marks on his chart the positions of his fleet, as follows, by means of crosses:
 One Battleship: four squares 
One Cruiser: 3 squares 
Two Destroyers : 2 squares each

The squares marked must be consecutive for each ship, and must be in a straight line, although they may be placed diagonally, vertically or horizontally. There must be, however, at least one blank square between any of the ships, and they must not touch each other. The players must not see each oher's charts and where their opponent's ships are placed.

Name: A.R.P.
Description:
Air Raid Precautions

The illustrations on the gameboard deal with jobs done and dangers encountered during the war years.

This game is a race game with rewards and forfeits along the 120 squares. The start is the air-raid drill and the finish is the All Clear sounding. The game was inspired by the air-raid precautions (ARP) put in place in Britain before the Second World War.

Name: F1 Wyścig
Description: In these exciting races players must properly dispose of the stock tires and fuel. Accelerating quickly consumes fuel but it gives you more move dices. Cornering the car loses a tire. When the fuel level and tire is low, the player must enter the car on the pitstop. After replenishing fuel and tires can continue to move to fight for victory.

Name: Legendy Polskie
Description: A player is unveiling the lost legends of Polish. Collect the cards and travel around the game board (map Polish). Players can exchange parts of the legends of the others. The player who accumulates the most points wins the game.

Name: Mad Scientist!
Description:
"Greetings, I am Doctor Milton Perfidious, anarchist and terror to the civilized world.  You have been selected as the top of your class to create things beyond your wildest dreams and to cause chaos in a world that shuns us and calls us MAD!  Today’s lesson will be in giant monster creation and the instigation of a rampage in said monster.  Now if you would please turn to page 13 in your text books..."

In Mad Scientist! you play the role of a mad scientist hell bent on the destruction of the civilized world.  Players will create giant monsters with spare parts around their "lab" and use them to battle other players’ monsters and to destroy or protect locations.  The player, who wreaks the most havoc, destroys the most locations and wins the most monster battles will be named the victor.  There are also special Degrees in mad science that can be earned throughout the game and they give you special skills that other players do not have access to, as well as actions you can take to foil your fellow mad scientists’ plans.

Name: Annie Wants Her Stripes
Description:
This is a boardgame published by the magazine Woman. It is a race game with help and hindrance along the way. It also reflects the fact that women were very much involved in the war effort during the Second World War.

On the gameboard one can see a snake pattern of squares with 18 illustrations and directions. On the right are the title, instructions and 4 playing pieces to be cut out.

Name: Shapy
Description: The players throw the three dice at one time and everyone looks together for the tile with the same shapes as those that come up on the dice. Different versions offer variety so that even older children and adults can have a lot of fun with Shapy.

Name: The Game of Steeplechase
Description: The gameboard is long and oval-shaped, and the 100 playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are still used, however, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed. This particular game is played anticlockwise. The game has five fences with a fallen horse and rider at the second. The centre illustration and the corners depict the race goers, the grandstand, coaches, horses and men and women.  In each of the corners is a scene from a horse race and in the space between the start and the finish the scene of gathering the horses ready for the race with the starter and his flag.

Name: Tastaro
Description:
The educational matching game that helps promote visual and tactile shape recognition while boosting memory skills at the same time. Different options of play and levels of difficulty mean that Tastaro is suitable for various different age groups and accelerates the learning curve in a fun way.

Contents:
• 8 wooden shapes  
• 32 wooden cards (45 x 45 x 4 mm) 
• 3 cotton pouches
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Imita
Description:
This game calls for quick perception and some imagination. To act, imitate or describe a wide variety of illustrations is fun and encourages creativity!

The players thrown the dice and places their figures on the first space with the colour shown on the dice. Now they have various options to explain the illustration to the other players. They can mime it, imitate the sound or explain the illustration without calling it by name. The first one to reach the goal wins the game.

Contents:
• 1 wooden game board (370 x 370 x 10 mm)
• 6 playing figures
• 1 colour dice  
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Scouting Tests
Description: A race game which starts at 'Enrolment' and moves counter clockwise. Accompanying the game are test cards and badges, which determine the rewards and forfeits. The winner is the one who reaches the Silver Wolf Badge.

Name: The New Game of Motor Tour: A journey of 440 miles from Edinburgh to London with incidents en route
Description:
The board is numbered from 1 (Start) to 100 (London) with 101 and 0 after 100. The winner is the one who lands on 100. If a player lands on 101, he must leave the game as he had been killed. If a throw takes a player to 0 or beyond, they must return to compartment 86.

The Motor Tour may be taken part in by as many players as there are motors/markers. Each player starts at number 1 and plays in turn and must go on to No 2, that is, throw 1 before he/she can get a motor to commence the tour. The towns meed not be called at, but if fall on a town the player misses a turn to view the sights. More than one motor can be on the same division at the same time, and motors can pass and re-pass each other. 
If fall on division marked with penalties or advantages, follow the instructions stated on the divisions.

Name: Motor Cycle Racing
Description: The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are used, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed. The game is played anticlockwise. The centre of the circuit shows a vivid, modern illustration of a motorcycle race in progress, with illustrations of cycles and people in each corner.

Name: Greyhound Racing
Description:
The playing surface is long and oval-shaped, and the playing spaces are narrow and angled. The basic rules of race games are still used however, with turns missed and players moving backwards and forwards as directed.

The hare must be advanced on its own track at the same time as the dogs. This is achieved by using two dice of different sizes, the smaller one for the hare. The dogs are moved by the players individually when their turn comes round, but the hare is moved at each throw of the dice.

To win, a dog can either land in the same compartment as the hair or pass the winning post, but the dogs may not pass the hare, and those that might, lose a turn. Losing a turn is also the penalty if a dog lands in a compartment already occupied as `it is supposed a fight ensues'.

Name: Piazza
Description:
It`s fun to go shopping! Particularly when you`re buying colourful and healthy food! Giving children the opportunity to buy the food and pay for it themselves delevops in them an awareness of nutrition, strategic thinking and an early understanding of quantities.

The players move their figures along the board and bit by bit they buy four different items of food (apples, peppers, maize and fish). They have money tokens to use to pay for them but they must make sure to get the food at the right price. The first to pay for these four food items is the winner.

Contents:
• 1 wooden playing board (appr. 370 x 370 x 10 mm) 
• 4 playing figures 
• 16 money tokens
• 1 dice with dots  
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Whatzizz??
Description:
A mirror is something wonderful. The reflecting surface shows an exact image of whatever is held in front of the mirror. It´s a little more difficult if you can only see part of what is reflected in it. You need concentration and imagination to figure out what it is.

Each player puts a card facing downwards on the mirror element. Now all the players guess one after another what the picture might be by looking at the section of the mirror facing them. The player who guesses correctly may take the card and the one who collects the most cards wins the game.

Contents:
• 1 mirror element (135 x 135 x 105 mm) 
• 60 motifs cards
• 5 empty cards to design yourselves
• 1 pen
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Funny Friends Rallye
Description:
This game with our "Funny Friends" is convenient for the youngest. Even two years children are able to follow easy instructions. The clear shapes and colours of the game are especially age oriented.

The animals run once on the racecourse on the playing field whereby the spinning arrow decides how far each animal may run in each go. The winner is the first animal to arrive back at his start or go beyond it.

Contents:
• 1 wooden game board (400 x 400 x 10 mm) 
• 4 playing figures
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Funny Friends Line
Description:
The small players thread the animals one by one according to the order of the cards. Once all animals have been threaded in the correct order and are placed in the middle of the table the game is over and all the players have won.

This game with our Funny friends is convenient for the youngest. Even at two years children are able to follow easy instructions and the game figures are extra big so that the small hand can grasp easily. The clear shapes and colours are especially age oriented.

Contents:
• 6 animals (dog, cat, sheep, horse, cow, pig) 
• 6 wooden cards 
• 1 string 
• 1 lacing stick
• 1 coloured Beleduc Box

Name: Sliced Nations
Description:
A card game where the cards each have a letter of the alphabet and part of an illustration. The aim is to collect all the cards for one nationality.

It must be said that this is an educational game and not a game in the Happy Family category.

Published in New York.

Name: Tamagotchi: El juego
Description:
Roll the Tama Roulette and start discovering the Tama Planet. His districts (Patchi Forest, GuruGuru City, Mame City and Tama City) and his inhabitants have numerous surprises. In each of your trips, a test  is waiting for you: a reunion with a Tamagotchi character, an unexpected expense, an exciting game, a card to collect...
But don’t forget your objective: collect the major number of cards and have the most points before the sunset!


 Haz girar la Tama ruleta y empieza a descubrir el Tama Planeta. Sus barrios (Bosque Patchi, Ciudad GuruGuru, Mame Ciudad y Tama Ciudad) y sus habitantes te reservan numerosas sorpresas. En cada uno de tus de tus desplazamientos, te espera una prueba: un reencuentro con un personaje Tamagotchi, un gasto imprevisto, un palpitante juego, una carta para coleccionar...
¡Pero no olvides tu misión: coleccionar el mayor número posible de cartas y reunir el máximo de puntos antes de que se ponga el sol!

Name: Hide & Seek with the Kings & Queens of England
Description:
A card game with the players trying to collect additional cards to create sets/tricks.

“First published in around 1865, when history meant learning the kings and queens, Jaques titled the 3 different games as Hide & Seek series 1 (William I - Richard II), Hide & Seek series 2 (Henry IV - Charles I) and Hide & Seek series 3 (Charles II - Victoria in the 1st edition or Edward VII in the 2nd edition). The first editions all had small pictures of the monarchs but the second editions had larger pictures in a more modern style looking like paintings. The game is played by players asking each other for the Event cards matching the King cards, completing sets, and so on.” - description taken from the World of Playing Cards website

Name: Game of Columbia's Presidents
Description: A card game which was designed to teach the names and dates of Columbia's Presidents. The cards has an illustration, dates, signature and names of associates. Collect cards and get tricks to win.

Name: Amusement for Beginners in French
Description:
Teach French with cards! 210 cards with pictures and names cut in half. The top half with English name and upper half of the picture, while the French name and the lower half of the picture is on the lower half of the card.

The game could be played by one person or in the same way as dominoes.

Name: The Multiplication Table in Rhyme
Description: This card game has 96 cards, each showing one half of an illustration and one half of a caption. Its aim is to teach multiplication in a fun way. Players must collect both halves and the completed picture should prompt the the particular sum.

Name: Mc Dowall's Musical Game
Description:
A game with 150 cards each printed with a question about music. The answers are all contained in an accompanying booklet. There are six classes of questions concerning different aspects of written music.

Class A contains Questions on the Form of the Characters, etc 
Class B Time, Rests Clefs, etc 
Class C The Names of the Lines and Spaces 
Class D Sharps, Flats, Accents, etc 
Class E Signs and Italian Terms used in Music 
Class F Scale, Major and Minor Keys.

Name: The New Game of Illustrated Proverbs
Description:
This game of 63 cards uses proverbs with humorous illustrations as its teaching tool. The idea of the game being to collect the words that make up the proverb.

The Twelve Proverbs are shuffled and dealt out to the players. The player on the left hand of the dealer commences the play by asking any other player for a card of any Proverb of which he holds one or more in his hand. If he obtains it he may continue asking until he asks for a card which the player asked does not hold. The right of asking in then transferred to him and he in the same way continues to ask till in like manner disqualified. When any player has obtained all the cards of a set forming the complete proverb, he turns them up on the table. The player who first completes all the Proverbs of which he holds cards at the commencement of the game, of which any cards remain to him as the game progresses, wins.

Name: The Royal Game of Mother Goose
Description:
Each card is printed with a title and illustration of a character, and a rhyming couplet. Each verse gives a moral lesson and a reward or forfeit.

Shuffle the cards and deal them out face downwards. The dealer commences by turning up a card and paying or receiving as directed on their card. The card with Mother Goose winning the pool and repeating the following words on turning up the card and making every player turn up whatever cards they have left:

Mother Goose by starlight flies 
On the air with golden prize, 
Her share will be the total hoard, 
When all are served she clears the board. 
The game all o'er her task is done, 
Her only aim to cause some fun. 
So now good night my children gay, 
For Goosey bids me haste away.

Name: The New Game of Animals
Description: There are 11 sets of cards. The lead card has a picture of an animal: an ass, cat, cow, dog, fox, goat, hare, horse, lion, pig or rat. The others in the set spell out the name of the animal with the letters illustrated in pictures. The set of lion cards is double in point value, because he is the 'king of the beasts'. The player who has obtained the largest number of sets at the end of the game wins.

Name: Spirakel
Description:
The game board depicts a colorful spiral. Each of the six colors has six base fields from which a spiral "arm" leads to the center of the board. The colors don't "belong" to any player. Instead, any player can use playing pieces in any color.

There are two rule sets included: 
In the "dice game", players take turns rolling four dice. With the results, they can put playing pieces on free spaces in the spiral. One die can be used to jump over another piece which is then returned to its base. When a player has occupied certain positions, he/she is awarded a number of scoring chips. The player with most chips at the end of the game is the winner.
The "board game" is a push your luck game. The pieces, which contain numbers from 1-6, are placed on their bases, face down. One piece of each color is flipped over and put on the corresponding position in that color's spiral. 
A player can now flip over pieces and move them into their position until he/she flips over a piece that is larger than a previously played piece in the same color. In that case, all pieces that were jumped over are moved back to their bases (behind the un-flipped pieces, in numerical order) and it's the next player's turn. The same scoring applies as in the dice game.

(User summary by HilkMAN - corrections welcome. The rules aren't easy to understand)

Name: The Guardians Masters of the Electroworld
Description:
From the box: "The Guardians, Angel, Logan, Destiny and Sky, help kids and parents through a maze of tough choices and everyday life situations. The object of the game is to make it home from school safely. Move forward by answering tough questions.

"Identifies areas where your child is at risk. Helps kids and parents express their feelings. Introduces ethical role models. Makes learning fun with interactive role play. Fosters a positive environment for family discussions. Teaches options for handling difficult situations."

User comment: Contains a colorful playing board which is a layout of several blocks and streets. School, fire department, bank, grocery store and other mainstays of small town America are depicted.

Name: Schwere Schritte
Description:
User Summary:

Edition Spielbox No. 88. First published in Spielbox 1/2010.

Players are hikers that are trying to cross a bridge. However the bridge is not stable and will collapse if there is ever too much weight on it.

Each player is secretly assigned one of six colours at the start of the game. The players throw the die in turn and make a number of moves with any pawns equal to the value rolled. Each space on the bridge has a weight score and if the sum of the pawns' weight is greater than the stability score of the bridge, it collapses. Pawns at the start and in the middle of the bridge fall into the river and swim back to the start, pawns near the end land on rocks and are eliminated.

If a player wishes to move his pawn to the goal and win, he must declare his intention to do so before rolling. The next player may then try and guess the roller's identity, with a correct guess eliminating that player from the game as well.

Name: BattleLore: Horrific Horde
Description:
From Fantasy Flight Games (publishers):

BattleLore: Horrific Horde provides forty-two additional figures for your BattleLore army, including two never-before-seen troop types, as well as even more of the primary Goblinoid staples that are available in both the core set and the Goblin Marauders expansion. With all these added units, Goblins will no longer be relegated to serving as mercenary forces for a standard human army. The time has come to let loose the fury of the Horde!

Contents:

     8-page rule booklet, including 5 new adventures
     42 figures:
         12 Goblin Halberdiers
         12 Goblin Swordsmen
         6 Ogres
         6 Hobgoblin Cavalry (=Lizard riders from BattleLore base set)
         6 Hobgoblin Hyena Riders (first appeared in BattleLore: Goblin Marauders Specialist Pack)
    
     14 banners (only 2 of which are of the fleur-de-lys type)
     2 Specialist cards (Ogres and Halberdiers)
     2 Unit Summary cards (Ogres, Hyena Riders)
     2 Weapon Summary cards (Slings, Halberds)
     1 Medieval Tactics card (Battle-Savvy troops)
     15 Goblin Deployment cards for BattleLore: Call to Arms


Expands:

     BattleLore

Name: Long Leg Wins
Description:
(From the instructions:)
"The game is very simple and can be played with young children.  Each of the players will have a great deal of fun as they try to make the longest leg."

(User Summary:)
A picture of a boy, without legs, is placed on the table.  Players draw tiles with sections of a leg and a number printed on them.  One or more tiles can be played each turn to extend one of the boy's legs, but may only be played if their values total 7 or 11.  Boot tiles force players to complete their leg, but must also follow the 7-11 rule.  The player who completes the longest leg wins the game.
